title: Africa Opensource Pharma & Medicine
description: Drug & medical funding is heavily centralised. Africa lacks investment & solutions despite native scientific talent.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal clearly states the problem in pharma and medicine in Africa and elaborates the steps with which the problem can be solved.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal has a high potential of successful implementation due to the experience and knowledge of the proposer in both the health sector and the blockchain network. With the plan presented, good supervision will help create success in the implementation of the project.
f6_assessments.q2: The budget does not clearly explain how much will be invested into each category of the project although it states the categories.

f6_assessments.q0: As someone deeply interested in science and social good I am impressed by this proposal. This proposal if implemented successfully using Cardano, could bring to life a huge market for scientific innovation in Africa - that's a good look for us! This proposal aims to drive growth in the African medical and biotech sectors. The discoveries made if the Fleming Protocol (which already has VC/accelerator backing) if successfully realised, could reduce human suffering and lead to a healthier happier world. The project is open sourced and seeking active colaboration, which fits with this challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: The team have already secured external funding from a legitimate crypto startup accelerator which gives a good indicator of commitment. The fact that this team have claimed collaboration with two universities and catalyst F5 success gives me some confidence that they can bring the plan to life. Unfortunately the team have not given enough detail about themselves and with a little detective work I have been unable to verify the claims above. I have emailed the Base Camp Accelerator for verification of the claims made but have not received any reply as yet. Some of the websites I found related to the partner Martin Codyre do not seem legitimate or just very abandoned. I would encourage the proposers to include more verifiable information about themselves. The paper that they have published on the Fleming Protocol is professional and an interesting read.
f6_assessments.q2: Unfortunately this proposal does not have sufficient information to give it a high rating in audibility. They have not specified any metrics to measure success and no roadmap or steps to completion have been put forward in this proposal. The budget has no breakdown other than 'to pay engineering team' but no further detail which the Cardano Community requires to make a good decision on ROI. It is a really worthwhile concept and I hope with community feedback the project proposal can be refined to meet Catalyst Assessment Guidelines and have great success in future rounds.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal clearly highlighted a problem and clearly explained the solution but from the description of the proposal, it is stated that this same project have been partially funded in Fund 5 as stated ("We are building on our successful bid in Fund 5 (see the previous Fund 5 proposal here:****https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/Africa-Opensource-Pharma-Medicine/352738-48088").It will be expected that a milestone is achieved before coming back to request for more funds (Achieved milestones for the fund 5 funding is not shown of discussed and the current state of the funded aspect).
Considering the above concerns i can neither Agree or disagree that this Solution address the challenge , leaning more to the lack information regarding the execution of the Fund 5 funds received.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal did not contain any verifiable links but a quick action by team included  a link (https://cardano.ideascale.com/userimages/accounts/93/936143/panel_upload_48088/Fleming-FBC-Part-4---OV_BaseCamp_One_Pager-b1bcf8.pdf) on the comment section of the proposal which is used to make a decision here.

The provided link proves given experience but the proposal lacks an implementation plan,This could be due to the fund 5 submission but clearly highlights why the milestones in the Fund 5 application need to be completed before requesting for further funds .
Considering the above, i do not agree that this second proposal request will be implemented .
f6_assessments.q2:
There is no information of timelines, milestones and cost breakdown.
I disagree this current proposal provided sufficient information for audit.

f6_assessments.q0: I approach this proposal with a little bit of bias as I had supported this project as a voter in Fund 5 and it is gratifying to see the progress and maturity in such a quick timeframe. It is one of the truly transformational projects Cardano brings to Africa not only because it has made available a platform from which Fleming could exist but because it also allows the mechanisms for self-sustainability when fully operational. There is a wealth in Africa that needs to be tapped and this project's outreach beyond the continent, with partnerships in European universities and organisations being critical to its success. It leverages local knowledge and expertise and opens a two-way transfer  with the rest of the world. The build in Haskell and in Plutus showcases Cardano's capabilities in such a respected industry. I wish the project well.
f6_assessments.q1: Based on the described partnerships and the state of the current GitHub build, there is a high degree of confidence the plan and its goals can be achieved. The proposer has the relevant experience in the pharmaceutical industry however it would have been preferred if links to a public profile could be provided for voters to validate. It also would have been useful if more than a general link to base-camp participation is added to the proposal. The main outlier ventures site does not provide a list of its winning participants where the claims could be validated. Most of the details presented on the proposal is geared towards ongoing business activities and partnerships and not heavy enough in details of Fleming development. Should this proposal not secure funds in this round, I suggest a re-write detailing more of Fleming activities. Good luck.
f6_assessments.q2: Descriptions that would have assisted the assessment of this project's auditability is quite minimal. From Fleming's point of view, its GitHub receptacle is publicly available for scrutiny. In terms of the timelines and milestones of the developments further required, there are no descriptions which can be confidently assessed. There is currently only one person who commits code to GitHub and there's no explanation as to whether all codes of a team are handled by a single user or if there is only one coder so far involved in the project. There needs to be more openness in terms of the build as it is foundational to the success of this protocol. It would also be helpful if linkages to prove the partnerships mentioned are provided as they also prove auditability of this proposal. They were mentioned in the fund 5 proposal and given this is fund 6, there is a higher expectation to prove that those partnerships are secured. If this proposal is not funded in this round, I recommend a better description of the team, their credentials, the timelines of the build and the goals for each milestone. Also, if the claimed Fleming MVP is released prior to the end of Fund 6, then it could be leveraged as proof of on-going progress and success and would align it more with Catalyst's requirements. Good luck.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal, now in its second phase, addresses a needed market and challenge (growing Africa) and helps to build a needed piece of healthcare R&D infrastructure that would bootstrap up the resources involved. It's a large task, and would be impressive to pull off. (Reviewer is a physician).
f6_assessments.q1: There are a lot of promising aspects to this proposal, including the plan and how use of stakepools leads to funding to the infrastructure, as well as making the development open source so as to not let the capitalistic/patent protections interfere with the public health benefits. Negatives are that the proposer, per fund 5 proposal (with no update since) is only in conversation with core technical experts such as the Cape Town professor, and does not appear to have gotten any of them agreed to participate in the project yet. There would need to be an entire technical infrastructure including institutional review boards, vetting of projects, etc, which are largely undetailed in this proposal, and is primarily focusing on getting the money flowing. Good. Could be better. How are the projects to be vetted? Who's actually signed on at this point in terms of technical experts, institutions, etc., even as much as LOIs?
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer seems to imply that this funding round would go towards launching of their MVP, but don't have a clear timeline or update since fund 5 of features included, metrics after of adoption or traction, etc. Will this be the launching of the app? The DAO? The OSP coin? What's the timeline and will they just be continuing to request follow-on funds with each Catalyst fund (which is of course fine but not spelled out). Their fund 5 proposal indicated finishing a white paper by now but that doesn't appear to be linked, either.

f6_assessments.q0: When complements the content of this proposal wiht the content of the F5 proposal (https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/Africa-Opensource-Pharma-Medicine/352738-48088),  the reader can see the solid knowledge of the proposers about the problematic and the appropiate conception of the solution.
f6_assessments.q1:
-  The proposal in F5 did not provide a budget clearly outline and broken down into identifiable items that permits give sense to the distribution of the funds assigned to that proposal (above the proposal mentions "our successful bid in Fund 5 ", so I suppose that the funds ($45000) were assigned).  In the actual proposal, once again, it does not presents a budget clearly outline and broken down into identifiable items.  So, that makes difficult to know what's the difference between the two proposal, because apparently they are the same.   As the proposers write in the page 12 of their white paper: " Proposals will have milestones so that $OSP tokens are not released all at once (to hold the user accountable). For example, if a user wants $100,000 worth of $OSP, the user must specify in their proposal how much is needed at each milestone (milestone 1: $30,000 worth of $OSP, Milestone 2: $70,000 worth etc). If a milestone is reached, the next stage of funds will be released."

-  Unlike the proposal in F5, this proposal does not provide a plan of implementation that permits to the voter knows about the characteristics of the progressive development of the proposal.  Or if, maybe, it has to read the proposal in F5 for more details.  

-  The proposal mentions that the destiny of the funds will be entirely for pay the engineering team. The proposal mention relevant skills and experience of the engineering team in charge but not provide a relation of the team members or references or links for check skills and experience (in an initial search the only technical member part of the engineering team was https://www.linkedin.com/in/bogicevicsasa/ , is he the only member of the Fleming protocol's engineering team? )

-   The proposal does not clearly explain technical aspects like architecture, language and tecnologies if they are crucial for implementation
f6_assessments.q2:
-	The proposal  does not present a roadmap with milestones and a time horizon for achievement.

-	The proposer does not present metrics/KPIs that define the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: It is working on a very challenging problem in Africa that addresses the challenge well.
f6_assessments.q1: It's a strong team with a diverse background according to the details in Fund 5, it can be expected to succeed in implementing it.
f6_assessments.q2: Requesting fund with a link to the previous fund proposal. It will be great to get more information about the reasoning behind the requested funding. In the proposal in Fund 5 it says "The majority of the funds will go towards MVP development (front and back end, smart contract development) which is estimated to take 3-4 months. Anything left over will go towards ongoing partnership development." Can you provide more details as to why you require 60.000 to continue building the MVP while in Fund 5 you needed 45.000?

solution: De-Fi platform leveraging stake pools to crowdfund open-source drug/medical projects, where scientific collaboration & governance is central
experience: Extensive exp in health/life sciences, academia, & deep understanding of the industry. Several scientific/tech advisors with decades of exp.
